Award.AwardTitle: Unraveling the Structural and Biomechanical Roles of Proteoglycans in Arterial Wall

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proteoglycans (PGs) contribute to the basic development and maintenance of arteries. While other structural molecules and cells, such as the elastic fibers, smooth muscle cells, and collagen fibers have received extensive attention, little is known about the structural and biomechanical roles of PGs in arteries. This ignorance is likely linked to the low mass fraction of PGs, and that they are thought to be most important mechanically in resisting compressive stresses. Using natural chemicals that can dissolve away only the proteoglycans the investigators will measure the changes of artery stiffness as the proteoglycans are removed. Also, a mathematical model will be created that includes how the proteoglycans connect between the other molecules in the tissue understand and predict how the preoteoglycan's work to create tissue stiffness. There is a pressing need for such information in order to understand diseases of the arteries and heart. Undergraduate and graduate students who work in the project will learn to work with biology and mathematical theory to prepare them for careers in biomedical research.

Given the complex interactions between PGs and other structural components, the overall goal of this research is to explore how PGs contribute to the structural and biomechanical integrity of arteries through coupled mechanical testing, advanced optical imaging, and microstructure-based constitutive modeling for charged hydrated tissues. With carefully designed experiments including local extracellular matrix structural and biochemical modification, this research takes a unique approach that integrates expertise in multi-photon microscopy, biaxial tensile testing, and structure-based mixture constitutive modeling to explore the contributions of PGs to the structural and biomechanical integrity of human arteries, and to understand alterations in structural and biomechanical roles of PGs in atherosclerosis. The important interplay between PGs and other extracellular matrix constituents will be incorporated into constitutive modeling by considering key structural information and osmotic effect. Results from the research will establish a solid foundation to investigate the mechanical roles of extracellular matrix constituents in the functionality of arteries, and launch quantitative mechanobiological understandings of vascular mechanics.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteoglycans (PGs) contribute to the fundamental development and maintenance of the structure and function of the arterial wall. Building upon our prior research on extracellular matrix (ECM) mechanics, in this project we studied how PGs contribute to the structural and biomechanical integrity of arteries through coupled biomechanical characterization, advanced optical imaging, and microstructure-based constitutive modeling. Biomechanical contribution of PGs was studied with an emphasis on elucidating the interactions between PGs and other ECM constituents. Multi-photon microscopy was used to provide microstructural assessment on individual ECM component. A user defined constitutive model was developed to incorporate collagen fiber recruitment in order to predict the stress-stretch behavior of PG depleted tissue. Overall, our study suggests that despite the relatively low mass fraction of PGs in arterial tissue, PGs play an important role in contributing to the structural and mechanical properties of the arterial wall.

Intellectual Merit

Results from this research establish a solid foundation to investigate the mechanical roles of ECM components in the functionality of arteries. With carefully designed experiments through ECM structural and biochemical modification, our study establishes several new fundamental concepts for the understanding of the role of PGs in arterial tissue at the structural and functional levels. Findings from our study advance our current understanding of complex soft tissue behavior and hold a great potential to unravel the underlying key mechanisms of vascular remodeling. Using a structure-based constitutive model that incorporates changes in collagen fiber recruitment, our study successfully predicts arterial stiffening based on earlier fiber recruitment due to enzymatic PG depletion. Our study provides new understandings on the relationship among ECM constituents such as elastin, collagen, and PGs; and how they interact and contribute to vascular mechanics. 

Broader Impacts

Studies of the structural components of arteries are generally focused on elastin and collagen, and PGs are often neglected, however the functional and regulatory significance of PGs has emerged as a promising field in all aspects of cell biology and human diseases. Results from this study may have clinical and physiological relevance to understanding mechanisms that affect vascular homeostasis and mechanobiology with associated alterations in PG content such as aging, diabetes and atherosclerosis. The social impacts of the proposed research will be broad. Educationally, we incorporated several educational initiatives into the proposed research program, and had more female graduate, undergraduate, and high school students involved in engineering and science research. The broad interdisciplinary nature of this project greatly benefitted the undergraduate/graduate students trained through this project. Research results were disseminated through journal publications and conference presentations and were also incorporated into undergraduate/graduate teaching and several BU outreach activities. 

 


Last Modified: 04/05/2020
Modified by: Katherine Y. Zhang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Proteoglycans (PGs) contribute to the fundamental development and maintenance of the structure and function of the arterial wall. Building upon our prior research on extracellular matrix (ECM) mechanics, in this project we studied how PGs contribute to the structural and biomechanical integrity of arteries through coupled biomechanical characterization, advanced optical imaging, and microstructure-based constitutive modeling. Biomechanical contribution of PGs was studied with an emphasis on elucidating the interactions between PGs and other ECM constituents. Multi-photon microscopy was used to provide microstructural assessment on individual ECM component. A user defined constitutive model was developed to incorporate collagen fiber recruitment in order to predict the stress-stretch behavior of PG depleted tissue. Overall, our study suggests that despite the relatively low mass fraction of PGs in arterial tissue, PGs play an important role in contributing to the structural and mechanical properties of the arterial wall. Intellectual Merit Results from this research establish a solid foundation to investigate the mechanical roles of ECM components in the functionality of arteries. With carefully designed experiments through ECM structural and biochemical modification, our study establishes several new fundamental concepts for the understanding of the role of PGs in arterial tissue at the structural and functional levels. Findings from our study advance our current understanding of complex soft tissue behavior and hold a great potential to unravel the underlying key mechanisms of vascular remodeling. Using a structure-based constitutive model that incorporates changes in collagen fiber recruitment, our study successfully predicts arterial stiffening based on earlier fiber recruitment due to enzymatic PG depletion. Our study provides new understandings on the relationship among ECM constituents such as elastin, collagen, and PGs; and how they interact and contribute to vascular mechanics. Results from this study may have clinical and physiological relevance to understanding mechanisms that affect vascular homeostasis and mechanobiology with associated alterations in PG content such as aging, diabetes and atherosclerosis. The social impacts of the proposed research will be broad. Educationally, we incorporated several educational initiatives into the proposed research program, and had more female graduate, undergraduate, and high school students involved in engineering and science research. The broad interdisciplinary nature of this project greatly benefitted the undergraduate/graduate students trained through this project. Research results were disseminated through journal publications and conference presentations and were also incorporated into undergraduate/graduate teaching and several BU outreach activities.
